bibl.title: Letter from the Acting Assistant Surgeon to Henry Rose Carter, May 23, 1923

div1.p: The writer reports that no vessels other than the Japanese are running between Asia and South American ports. The writer also notes that yellow fever is extinguished in Peru.

div1.head: Letter from the Acting Assistant Surgeon to Henry Rose Carter, May 23, 1923
div1.opener:
CALLAO-PERÚ
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
Callao, Peru, May 23rd.,1923.
Assistant Surgeon General H.R. Carter,
U.S. Public Health Service,
Washington, D.C.
Sir:-
div1.p:
I have the honor to acknowledge receipt
your letter dated April 18, 1923, (/LC.) inquiring for data
on the traffic from the west coast to eastern Asia in order
to prevent the danger of the introduction of yellow fever
into Australia directly or via the south east of Asia.

In reply I include herewith the data of the Japanese Line
making travel in this coast. At present no other vessels
are running between Asia and South American ports. There is
a Chinese steamer for Chinese immigrants running from Hong
Kong to this coast every four months, but she does not touch
in any Equadorian port neither more there up than Balboa,
C.Z.

In Peru, the yellow fever was absolutely extinguished,
as you know.
div1.closer:
Very respectfully, IDlash
Actg. Asst. Surgeon.
